image.altText: A staff member touches a man's head while he lies in bed.

items.synopsis: Public hospitals in Bundaberg and Mackay have already re-introduced compulsory mask wearing with significant numbers of Omicron and flu cases circulating together across the state for the first time.

title.children: Some Queensland hospitals are mandating masks again as COVID and flu admissions rise

image.altText: A blue 'for lease' sign outside of a house.

items.synopsis: Research shows mortgage borrowers are paying the highest share of their income on housing costs in at least four decades, but the current situation for renters is not historically unusual.

title.children: Mortgage borrowers have never done it tougher, while renters are back to where they were in 2019

image.altText: A satellite image shows Nova Kakhovka Dam in Kherson.

items.synopsis: On the morning the Nova Kakhova dam was blown up in southern Ukraine, resident Hanna Zarudnia woke to both shelling and flooding. Then she was "surrounded by water from all sides".

title.children: 'The volume of water is colossal': The moment a Ukrainian dam was destroyed and the war changed forever

image.altText: Young white man with dark short hair and facial hair faces the camera with a neutral expression in a park. his arms are crossed

items.synopsis: Needle spiking is when a person is injected with a drug without their consent, and it's unknown how much it's happening in Australian venues.

title.children: Two friends blacked out while at a bar. Then they found the needle prick

image.altText: A person wearing black gloves and a hooded jacket uses a screwdriver to unscrew a number plate.

items.synopsis: Criminal networks are using stolen number plates to commit offences and avoid police, but there are simple solutions to stop your car becoming a target.

title.children: Thieves are targeting number plates — how can you protect yours from being stolen?

image.altText: A mine shaft

items.synopsis: Australian critical minerals will be more important than ever to fuel growing renewables demand amid dwindling supplies, according to Evolution Mining, which just extended its mine life 17 years.

title.children: Major copper mine extends life to 2040 as global renewables demand rises, supply issues loom

image.altText: Brittany Higgins crying while making a statement outside court.

items.synopsis: The Canberra Rape Crisis Centre has called out the Australian media for its reporting surrounding sexual assault and says journalists have been contacting it about Brittany Higgins.

title.children: Canberra rape support centre says journalists contacted it for information on Brittany Higgins

image.altText: Cattle walk over a huge mountain of landfill, mostly comprised of old clothes.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest fashion retailers are being threatened with a mandatory levy on garment sales, after many big names failed to sign up to a new scheme to tackle the 200,000 tonnes of old clothes going into landfill each year.

title.children: Just six Australian fashion giants sign up to a scheme to tackle their industry's waste problem

image.altText: Portrait of an older woman with short grey hair. She's got a red top on and a black jacket.

items.synopsis: It's deflating to start a new job only to realise what it seemed like on paper doesn't match the reality. Here's how to avoid getting trapped.

title.children: Why 'passion' is the one of the most 'dangerous words' an employer could ask for

image.altText: A sketch of prince harry sitting in front of a microphone in a courtroom

items.synopsis: Prince Harry is grilled in court as the Mirror Newspaper Group's legal team seeks to discredit his allegations that its journalists engaged in unlawful information-gathering practices to publish stories about him.

title.children: Prince Harry doubles down on 'incredibly suspicious' Mirror articles as he is cross examined in court

image.altText: Philip Lowe sitting at a desk behind a microphone mid-sentence, gesturing with his right hand and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe and his board have pushed up interest rates yet again – for the twelfth time in 14 months – because they want to damage the economy further, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Why Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe wants to damage the economy further

image.altText: Family of six stand smiling at camera wearing rural shirts and jeans

items.synopsis: Boarding school can be the difference between families staying or leaving their rural communities – but the cost leaves many tens of thousands of dollars out of pocket. That’s about to change due to a "game-changing" commitment.

title.children: Boarding school families 'ecstatic' after allowance boosted by $4,000

image.altText: Sheep in the rain on a farm property with two trees in the background.

items.synopsis: The way sheep grazier warnings are issued has been reviewed due to what many farmers consider "over-forecasting" of the risk to their livestock.

title.children: Graziers have spoken on weather alerts — and the BOM listened

image.altText: The Iranian flag  is shown with the new hypersonic missile called "fattah'.

items.synopsis: Iran presents what officials describe as its first domestically made hypersonic ballistic missile, an announcement likely to heighten Western concerns about Tehran's missile capabilities.

title.children: Iran unveils hypersonic ballistic missile 'capable of penetrating all defence shields'

image.altText: A purple, white and red card stacked beside each other

items.synopsis: The bank launched the cards to help those who have vision impairments.

title.children: How these new bank cards could make the lives of vision-impaired people easier

image.altText: Unidentified woman with a tissue, image from Pixabay

items.synopsis: Our noses perform some important functions every day of our lives, but we often only notice when disease changes how they work, writes David King.

title.children: Snot comes in many colours depending on what's happening up your nose. But be careful with how you use nasal spray

image.altText: A close up shot of a woman holing and looking at her newborn baby in a hospital bed.

items.synopsis: Women of migrant backgrounds are more at risk of developing some pregnancy complications, which can limit their choices for their pregnancy care and lead to more medical interventions during birth.

title.children: Caitlin planned for a water birth, but a diagnosis in labour changed everything

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: Investors are awaiting the latest economic growth figures in the wake of the Reserve Bank raising interest rates. Meanwhile, US stocks have increased. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Philip Lowe set to speak on why RBA delivered another rate rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Do you still use cheques? Treasurer Jim Chalmers says they will be phased out by 2030 as fewer people use them. The use of cheques has fallen by more than 90 per cent over the last ten years with consumers preferring to use internet or mobile banking. Commonwealth government departments will move to new forms of payments by 2028. Here's more from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cheques to be phased out by 2030

children.content: Do you still use cheques?
Treasurer Jim Chalmers says they will be phased out by 2030 as fewer people use them.
The use of cheques has fallen by more than 90 per cent over the last ten years with consumers preferring to use internet or mobile banking.
Commonwealth government departments will move to new forms of payments by 2028.
Here's more from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Commonwealth Bank has been fined a record $3.55 million for breaching spam email laws. Communications regulator the Australian Communications and Media Authority says the bank sent more than 65 million unlawful marketing emails between November 2021 and November 2022. Around 61 million of the emails unlawfully required customers to log-in to unsubscribe. ACMA also accepted a three year court enforceable undertaking from CBA which requires the bank to improve its practices and carry out an independent review of its e-marketing. ACMA chair Nerida O'Loughlin says it's important that companies make it easy to unsubscribe from marketing materials. "The scale and duration of the breaches by the CBA is alarming, especially when the ACMA gave it early warnings it might have some issues and the steps it took were ineffective," she said. "The failure to fix the issues shows a complete disregard for the spam rules and the rights of customers." "We sending a strong message that the ACMA will continue to look very closely at the telemarketing practices of large businesses and we will hold them account against the spam rules where we find non compliance." The Commonwealth Bank says the vast majority of the breaches occurred when it updated its electronic banking customer terms and conditions in November 2021. “We acknowledge and accept the findings of ACMA’s investigation into CBA’s compliance with certain provisions of the Spam Act," said CBA head of marketing and corporate affairs, Monique Macleod. "We apologise to all customers impacted by these issues which should not have occurred." "We’ve fixed the problem and are making changes to ensure it doesn’t happen in the future."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA fined for spam emails

children.content: The Commonwealth Bank has been fined a record $3.55 million for breaching spam email laws.
Communications regulator the Australian Communications and Media Authority says the bank sent more than 65 million unlawful marketing emails between November 2021 and November 2022.
Around 61 million of the emails unlawfully required customers to log-in to unsubscribe.
ACMA also accepted a three year court enforceable undertaking from CBA which requires the bank to improve its practices and carry out an independent review of its e-marketing.
ACMA chair Nerida O'Loughlin says it's important that companies make it easy to unsubscribe from marketing materials.
"The scale and duration of the breaches by the CBA is alarming, especially when the ACMA gave it early warnings it might
have some issues and the steps it took were ineffective," she said.
"The failure to fix the issues shows a complete disregard for the spam rules and the rights of customers."

"We sending a strong message that the ACMA will continue to look very closely at the telemarketing practices of large businesses and we will hold them account against the spam rules where we find non compliance."
The Commonwealth Bank says the vast majority of the breaches occurred when it updated its electronic banking customer terms and conditions in November 2021.
“We acknowledge and accept the findings of ACMA’s investigation into CBA’s compliance with certain provisions of the Spam Act," said CBA head of marketing and corporate affairs, Monique Macleod.
"We apologise to all customers impacted by these issues which should not have occurred."
"We’ve fixed the problem and are making changes to ensure it doesn’t happen in the future."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US Securities and Exchange Commission has also taken action against crypto exchange Coinbase. The SEC accused it of illegally operating an unregistered exchange in the US. The SEC said Coinbase has made billions of dollars since at least 2019 by operating as a middleman on crypto transactions, while evading disclosure requirements meant to protect investors. Ten US states have also accused Coinbase of securities law violations. Coinbase chief executive Brian Armstrong was unrepentant and says the company will defend the case. "Regarding the SEC complaint against us today, we're proud to represent the industry in court to finally get some clarity around crypto rules." The case is the SEC's second in two days against a major crypto exchange. Coinbase and Binance account for nearly 60 per cent of crypto transactions in May 2023 according to Reuters. Coinbase shares slumped 12.1 per cent overnight.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US regulator sues Coinbase

children.content: The US Securities and Exchange Commission has also taken action against crypto exchange Coinbase.
The SEC accused it of illegally operating an unregistered exchange in the US.
The SEC said Coinbase has made billions of dollars since at least 2019 by operating as a middleman on crypto transactions, while evading disclosure requirements meant to protect investors.
Ten US states have also accused Coinbase of securities law violations.
Coinbase chief executive Brian Armstrong was unrepentant and says the company will defend the case.
"Regarding the SEC complaint against us today, we're proud to represent the industry in court to finally get some clarity around crypto rules."
The case is the SEC's second in two days against a major crypto exchange.
Coinbase and Binance account for nearly 60 per cent of crypto transactions in May 2023 according to Reuters.
Coinbase shares slumped 12.1 per cent overnight.

image.altText: A pair of hands prepares to tear up a piece of paper labelled "reward for experience".

items.synopsis: A campaign designed to kill off the government's proposed "same job, same pay" changes has been launched. So what do we know about what the government is looking to achieve?

title.children: Same job, same pay: A matter of fairness or a 'dangerous' attack on business?

image.altText: Aryna Sabalenka waits at the net after winning her quarter final match as Ukraine's Elina Svitolina walks past

image.altText: A young man in a blue t-shirt speaks while an Indonesian officer watches

items.synopsis: An Australian man accused of going on a naked, drunken rampage in Indonesia will be released from prison after more than a month in detention.

title.children: 'I made a fool of myself': Australian arrested over drunken rampage in Indonesia freed after compo deal

image.altText: Chris Christie is seated and speaking into microphones during a news conference

items.synopsis: Chris Christie, who served as an adviser to Donald Trump's successful 2016 campaign but has since been an outspoken critic of the former president, has filed paperwork declaring his candidacy.

title.children: Trump backer turned critic Chris Christie enters US presidential race

image.altText: Three surgeons work together in a hospital.

items.synopsis: Federal independent MPs say a culture of public servants "bending to political will" is undermining fairness in government spending and leading to "pork barrelling".

title.children: 'It'll have enormous flow on impact': Independents call for action after hospital rorts

image.altText: Kathleen Folbigg, as a younger woman with long dark hair, looks at the camera and smiles.

items.synopsis: Kathleen Folbigg spent 20 years in jail for killing her children. The NSW Attorney General has now extended an unconditional pardon. But there are psychological and practical challenges ahead. Here's what the research tells us.

title.children: Kathleen Folbigg's release from prison might seem like a storybook ending but some challenges are just beginning

image.altText: Steve Smith shakes hands with Virat Kohli

items.synopsis: Australia and India meet at The Oval to decide the ICC World Test Championship but, with the Ashes looming, how much are Australia focused on this one-off match?

title.children: Australia takes on India in the World Test Championship — but what is it?

image.altText: Australian cricket captain Pat Cummins walks beside a green-top pitch at The Oval in the lead-up to a Test match.

items.synopsis: Amid climate protests in London, Australian Test cricket captain Pat Cummins hopes activists will not try to destroy The Oval pitch during the World Test Championship final between Australia and India.

title.children: Guard up at The Oval as Cummins hopes protesters stay off the pitch

image.altText: A man with white hair and check shirt sits with his arm around a brown Kelpie.

items.synopsis: It may sound like Tinder for older Australians, but the Seniors for Seniors program is about finding the special kind of love only a four-legged friend can provide.

title.children: After a record-breaking three years in the shelter and foster care, Janet the Kelpie has found her forever home

image.altText: red blue and whit sign in front of a tall building and car park

items.synopsis: An independent investigation is underway and a review has been conducted after a group of 30 women complain about maternity care they received at the Wagga Wagga Base Hospital in the NSW Riverina.

title.children: Investigation underway after 30 women complain about maternity experience at NSW hospital

image.altText: Man sits on bed writing

items.synopsis: A year ago, Thomas was a home owner. Now he expects to wait years before securing social housing.

title.children: 'I need a roof over my head': More facing homelessness as social housing stocks fall

image.altText: A smiling Ange Postecoglou stands on a stage holding a trophy with green and white ribbons, as another cup stands on a podium.,

items.synopsis: It's official — Ange Postecoglou leaves Celtic to make history as the first Australian to manage a Premier League team, with Spurs confirming he has signed a four-year contract.

image.altText: A man sits at a table wearing a cap and looking straight ahead.

items.synopsis: The PGA Tour, European Tour and rival Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit announce a landmark agreement to merge and form a commercial entity to unify golf.

title.children: PGA Tour agrees to merge with Saudi-backed LIV Golf
